gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.subtitle: Welcome to the Web Tools API documentation. Learn how to integrate our services into your application.
gettingStarted.overviewDesc: Web Tools provides a comprehensive suite of APIs to help you manage translations, error tracking, and analytics for your applications. This documentation will guide you through:
gettingStarted.overviewItem1: Authenticating with our API using project tokens
gettingStarted.overviewItem2: Setting up automatic error handling and reporting
gettingStarted.overviewItem3: Integrating our SDK into your application
gettingStarted.authDesc: Learn how to authenticate your requests using project tokens
gettingStarted.errorDesc: Set up automatic error tracking and reporting
gettingStarted.packageDesc: Install and configure our npm package
gettingStarted.prerequisitesDesc: Before you begin, ensure you have:
gettingStarted.prerequisiteItem2: A project created in your organization
gettingStarted.prerequisiteItem3: Your project token from the project settings
gettingStarted.supportDesc: Need help? Our support team is here to assist you. Reach out through:
gettingStarted.supportGithub: GitHub: Report issues and feature requests

authentication.title: Authentication
authentication.subtitle: Access to our API requires a project token.
authentication.getTokenInSettings: You can create or view your project token in Project Settings.
authentication.requireToken: You must send your project token in the request header. Without it, or with an invalid token, requests will fail with 401.
authentication.error401Missing: Token missing — the X-Project-Token header was not sent.
authentication.error401Invalid: Invalid or unauthenticated token — the token is wrong or not recognized.

errorHandling.title: Error Handling
errorHandling.subtitle: Capture and report errors from your app to Web Tools.
errorHandling.usageDesc: Wrap your app with our layout. Set your project token in .env (e.g. WEBTOOLS_PROJECT_TOKEN). Errors will be sent to our API automatically.

i18nPage.title: i18n Module
i18nPage.subtitle: Internationalization and translation management for your application.
i18nPage.overviewDesc: The i18n module provides tools for managing translations, locale switching, and localized content across your application. It integrates with Web Tools to sync translations from your project.
i18nPage.setupDesc: Add the i18n provider to your root layout and configure your default locale and supported languages. Messages are loaded from the messages folder or fetched from the API.
i18nPage.configurationDesc: Configure supported locales, fallback language, and message namespaces. You can use next-intl or a custom solution that syncs with your Web Tools project translations.
i18nPage.usageDesc: Use the useTranslations hook for component-level translations, and set up the language switcher so users can change the locale. Translation keys are synced with your project in the dashboard.

packageSetup.title: Package Setup
packageSetup.subtitle: Complete guide to installing and configuring the Web Tools SDK.
packageSetup.overviewDesc: The Web Tools SDK provides a comprehensive solution for integrating translations, error tracking, and analytics into your application. This guide covers the complete setup process.
packageSetup.prerequisitesDesc: Before you begin, ensure you have:
packageSetup.prerequisiteItem2: A Web Tools account and project
packageSetup.prerequisiteItem3: Your project token from project settings
packageSetup.installationDesc: Install the Web Tools SDK package:
packageSetup.environmentConfigDesc: Create a .env file in your project root and add your configuration:
packageSetup.nextjsSetupDesc: For Next.js applications, configure the SDK in your root layout:
packageSetup.typescriptSupportDesc: The SDK includes full TypeScript support. Create a type declaration file for your translations:
packageSetup.testingDesc: Mock the Web Tools SDK in your tests:
packageSetup.verificationDesc: Verify your setup is working correctly:
packageSetup.verifyConsoleDesc: In development mode, the SDK logs initialization status to the console
packageSetup.verifyTestErrorDesc: Use the error tracker to send a test error and verify it appears in your dashboard
packageSetup.verifyTranslationsDesc: Verify that translations are loading from your project
packageSetup.troubleshoot1Item2: Check that environment variables are being loaded
packageSetup.troubleshoot1Item3: Ensure you're using the latest SDK version
packageSetup.troubleshoot2Item3: Ensure you're in the correct environment
packageSetup.troubleshoot2Item4: Check network tab for API request errors
packageSetup.troubleshoot3Item1: Verify translations exist in your project
packageSetup.troubleshoot3Item2: Check the fallback locale is configured
packageSetup.nextStepsDesc: Now that you have the SDK set up, explore these resources:
packageSetup.nextStep3: Check out example projects on GitHub
